subhead: The issue of works being plundered to train generative artificial intelligence search engines remains unsettled. Negotiations between representatives of creators and generative AI systems to reach a licensing agreement appear to be stalling.

In Belgium, the migration minister is advocating for 'the strictest policy ever implemented'
subhead: Anneleen Van Bossuyt has taken a hard line on migration and integration policy, while distancing herself from Vlaams Belang, the powerful far-right party in Flanders.

headline: Fast-spreading Grand Canyon wildfires force tourist evacuations
subhead: The Dragon Bravo Fire was 0% contained on Friday evening, sparking the evacuation of visitors and residents from the national park's northern rim. The White Sage Fire, an even larger blaze, has scorched roughly 10,973 acres of land.

headline: Tracking neural implants that fool the immune system
subhead: To reduce the body's rejection response – which can impair the effectiveness of neural implants – an international team of researchers has chemically bonded these devices with an anti-inflammatory drug.

headline: Thomas Piketty: 'The US's unprecedented financial fragility explains Trump's aggressiveness'
subhead: The idea of spontaneously harmonious free trade does not stand up to scrutiny. Faced with imbalances, the right response would be to establish a common currency, argues the economist in his column.

US warns ICC member states to drop proceedings against Israel
subhead: Washington has threatened the International Criminal Court with further reprisals if it maintains arrest warrants against Benjamin Netanyahu and former Israeli defense minister Yoav Gallant. The US has already imposed sanctions on five judges and prosecutors.

headline: Donald Trump, the White House decorator-in-chief
subhead: During his cabinet meeting on Tuesday, July 8, the president digressed on a wide variety of topics for more than an hour and a half in front of the press.

headline: In Tunisia, migrants are driven out and their defenders prosecuted
subhead: '2015-2025: Europe's migration crisis' (5/5). For the past two years, the administration of Tunisian President Kais Saied, funded by the European Union, has been pushing sub-Saharan Africans far from cities, sometimes violently, and cracking down on any person or non-profit organization that supports them.
